instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.TPS51980: What is TPS51980? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1286 Macbook Pros,  A1297 Macbook Pros,  A1369 Macbook Airs,  A1466 Macbook Airs,  A1370 Macbook Airs,  and A1465 Macbook Airs.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: 3476 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> pulsing 5-3-5-3-5 etc
threads.message: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Presented with no liquid damage, however <RESISTOR>R5193</RESISTOR> an <RESISTOR>R5699</RESISTOR> were blown, and pad on <RESISTOR>R5193</RESISTOR> pp3v42 was gone. Ran a jumper to it.  still no fan spin. Started through the rails. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> seems to be pulsing betwixt 5 and 3 volts... not normal is it?

threads.title: 3476 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> pulsing 5-3-5-3-5 etc
threads.message: Those resistors don't "blow" This was a liquid damage case. <SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> is probably pulsing, is <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulsing too?

threads.title: 3476 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> pulsing 5-3-5-3-5 etc
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 27728"]Those resistors don't "blow" This was a liquid damage case. <SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> is probably pulsing, is <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulsing too?[/QUOTE]

It's hard to say liquid damage. But I did mean corrosion on those two when I said "blow". It would be weird because there is no other evidence of liquid infiltration. Just those two little r's. Nonetheless <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  and <SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> are both pulsing all over the place.

threads.title: 3476 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> pulsing 5-3-5-3-5 etc
threads.message: Check for short on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, else it could be crap under SMC or bad <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP>.
